cluster_relations.rel_desc: The austenitic structure is normally found in 300 Series austenitic stainless steels.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.
remarks: Complements the alloy→structure relation by capturing where the structure is typically present.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ferritic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).
Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Inverse perspective of the duplex→austenitic structural relation, included for coverage of where the austenitic phase is found.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

Upstream extraction infers that low alloy steels are a relevant host material for Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC), but the source text only explicitly mentions steels in general. Consider human review to confirm that HIC should be explicitly linked to low alloy steels as a family, or whether a more generic steel host entity would be preferable.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization occurs in low alloy C-Mo steels containing up to 1% Mo.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules are present in carbon steels as products of carbide decomposition at elevated temperatures.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.
remarks: Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.
Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules can also occur in 0.5Mo steels under elevated temperature conditions.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: The subject phase, microstructural feature, damage mechanism, or process occurs within or in association with the object material or alloy, which serves as its host environment.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: carbide phase decomposition associated with graphitization

remarks: Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.
Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.

args.remark: Upstream extraction infers that low alloy steels are a relevant host material for Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC), but the source text only explicitly mentions steels in general. Consider human review to confirm that HIC should be explicitly linked to low alloy steels as a family, or whether a more generic steel host entity would be preferable.
args.justification: The current relation assumes low alloy steel as a representative subset of steels susceptible to HIC, while the supporting text does not explicitly restrict or name low alloy steels. This semantic leap is noted in the existing remarks and the confidence score is low (0.38), so an explicit flag for potential over-specification is helpful for later curation.
